Tepamatr a N. Laosiripojana a S. Charojrochkul b ⁎ a The Joint Graduate School of Energy and Environment, King Mongkut’s University of Technology Thonburi, Bangkok 10140, Thailand The Joint Graduate School of Energy and Environment King Mongkut’s University of Technology Thonburi Bangkok 10140 Thailand b National Metal and Materials Technology Center, NSTDA, Pathumthani 12120, Thailand National Metal and Materials Technology Center NSTDA Pathumthani 12120 Thailand ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In the present work, the water gas shift activities of Cu on ceria and Gd doped ceria were studied for a further enhancement of hydrogen purity after a steam reforming process. The catalytic properties of commercial catalysts were also studied to compare with our as-prepared catalysts. It was found that copper-containing cerium oxide is suitable for the high temperature reaction. Copper-ceria is a stable high-temperature shift catalyst, unlike iron-chrome catalysts which are deactivated severely in CO2-rich gases. 5%Cu/10%GDC (D) was found to have much higher activity than other copper ceria based catalysts. Finely dispersed CuO species is more favorable due to a higher activity, which explains the activity enhancement of this catalyst. The kinetics of the WGS reaction over Cu catalysts supported by mixed oxide materials were measured in the temperature range 200–400°C. An independence of the CO conversion rate on CO2 and H2 was observed. To improve the catalytic performance of copper catalysts, the behavior of the bimetallic catalysts was compared with that of the monometallic catalysts. It was found that an addition of Re to Cu/GDC significantly improved the activity of copper catalysts. The effect of Re on enhancing the WGS activity of Cu catalysts was due to Re increases the reducibility of the surface ceria, In addition, Re contributes to reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+. The presence of Ce2O3 at the ceria surface gives rise to oxygen vacancies which facilitate the electron movement at the surface leading to ease of surface reduction. Keywords Water gas shift Cu Re Ceria 1 Introduction Hydrogen fuel cell is one of the most efficient and environmentally friendly type of an energy conversion device. It has a high potential in mitigating effects of climate change. Recently, there has been a renewed interest in the WGS reaction to supply hydrogen to a fuel-cell power generation [1,2]. Water-gas shift (WGS) reaction is an important step in fuel processors for preliminary CO clean up and generating additional hydrogen. The WGS process is exothermic (ΔH=−41.1kJ/mol). CO conversion is favoured at low temperature. However, a low temperature reaction is kinetically limited. To attain a good yield of hydrogen at low temperature enough to overcome a thermodynamic limit, two stages WGS catalysts is employed. A WGS process consists of high temperature WGS (HTS) and low temperature WGS (LTS). Conventionally, iron-chromium oxide and copper-zinc oxide catalysts have been used for HTS at 350–500°C [3,4] and for LTS at 200–250°C, respectively [5–11]. Fe2O3 Cr2O3 catalyst can effectively reduce CO from several percentage points to the equilibrium CO value dictated. Further reduction of CO takes place at low temperatures over a more active catalyst based on Cu-ZnO. The Cu-ZnO catalyst is very sensitive to temperature excursions, operating in the narrow temperature window of 200–250°C; requires careful activation in H2 gas; and is readily deactivated when exposed to air or by water condensation [12]. An optimization of the WGS system for the production of hydrogen for fuel cells is of particular interest among this energy industry. The high-temperature shift (HTS) can be used to increase the hydrogen content of coal gas produced by gasification or of reformate gas. The choice of copper-ceria for HTS contains a nonprecious metal hence, it would be a much more cost-effective catalyst for the intended application. It is also a better choice than nickel-ceria, which catalyzes the methanation reaction [13–15] and it has even better activity than gold-ceria at high temperatures [16,17]. In this work, Cu-containing ceria catalysts were examined as an alternative to the commercial iron-chrome HTS catalysts. Commercial catalyst formulations containing iron oxide were recently found to be deactivated in CO2-rich gases [18]. The effect of Cu and Re monometallic and bimetallic impregnation over ceria-based materials on the WGS reaction performance will be studied with an aim to maximize the yield of hydrogen production from the reforming gas. To understand the catalyst characteristics, the catalyst will be characterized using BET surface area, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) on top of the catalytic performance study. 2 Experimental procedure 2.1 Catalysts preparation Cerium oxide and gadolinium doped ceria (GDC) were prepared by a combustion synthesis technique [19] using urea as a fuel. Nitrate salts of cerium (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.5%, Alfa Aesar) and gadolinium (Gd(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.9%, Alfa Aesar) were used as initial chemical reactants. The stoichiometry between metal nitrate and urea was 2.5:1. Nitrate salts of cerium (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O) and urea were mixed for the preparation of cerium oxide. For the preparation of gadolinium doped ceria (GDC), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and Gd(NO3)3·6H2O were mixed with urea as the desired ratio. A minimum amount of deionized water was added to the mixed reactant to obtain a homogenous solution. The crucible containing the mixed reactant was then heated using a Bunsen burner until an autoignition occurred. The catalytic properties of CeO2 (AlfaAesar), CeO2 (Nanophase), 10% gadolinia-doped ceria (Daiichi) and 10% gadolinia-doped ceria (FuelCellMaterials), which denoted as A–D, were also studied to compare with the as-prepared catalysts. Copper (II) nitrate trihydrate; Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (Sigma-Aldrich) and ammonium perrhenate; NH4ReO4 (Sigma-Aldrich) were prepared by impregnation method. Appropriate amount of metal nitrate was dissolved in a minimal amount of deionized water. The salts solution was added to CeO2 (Alfa Aesar), CeO2 (Nanophase), 10% gadolinium doped ceria (FuelCellMaterials), 10% gadolinium doped ceria (Daiichi), CeO2 (prepared by combustion synthesis method) and 10% gadolinium doped ceria (prepared by combustion synthesis method). All the catalysts were dried at 110°C for 12h and then calcined at 650°C for 8h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 Standard characterization Specific surface areas (m2/g) and pore size distribution were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77.3K using Quantachrome NOVA 1200e. The specific surface area of the sample was calculated following the Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) procedure in the range of 0.05–0.3. Prior to the measurements, the samples were outgassed in vacuum at 300°C for 6h. The XRD diffractograms presented in this study were recorded employing nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406Å) operating at 40kV and the current was 40mA. The analyses were carried out at 0.02° step and 0.5s per step over a 2θ range of 20–80°. The crystallite sizes of the samples, d hkl , were estimated from Scherrer’s equation. (1) dhkl = 0.9λ/FWHM cos θ where λ is the X-ray wavelength of Cu K∝ radiation (1.5406A°), FWHM is the broadening (in radians) at half-maximum of the (1 1 1) crystallographic plane which is the most intense peak and θ is the diffraction angle corresponding to the (1 1 1) plane. 2.2.2 Temperature programmed reduction TPR experiments were performed under a flow of 5%H2/95%Ar mixture over 0.05g of catalyst from 40°C to 1000°C using a heating rate of 10°C/min. Prior to the measurement, the catalysts were treated under high purity helium gas at 120°C for 30min. The amount of H2 uptake during the reduction was measured by using a thermal conductivity detector. The curves in H2-TPR profile correspond to H2 consumption. 2.2.3 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) SEM images were taken on a FE-SEM (HITACHI SU-8030) with high vacuum mode using secondary electrons and an acceleration of 30kV. Samples were analyzed by spreading them on a carbon tape. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was used in connection with SEM for the elemental analysis. The elemental mapping was also collected with the same spectrophotometer. 2.2.4 CuO dispersion CuO dispersion in all catalysts was determined by N2O chemisorption using 10% N2O/He with a flow rate of 30mL/min at 50°C with BELCAT-B instrument. Sample preparation was conducted prior to the measurement as follows: about 50mg of each catalyst sample was loaded in a quartz tube. The sample was first heated to 120°C while flowing 100% Ar and held at this temperature for 10min. Then, the sample was heated up to 300°C in 5% H2/He and then kept at this temperature for 30min. The sample was then purged using 100% He with a flow rate of 30mL/min at 300°C for 15min and cooled to 50°C for measurement of CuO dispersion. 2.2.5 X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) The oxidation states of copper in each sample were identified using X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) on the beamline 8 of Synchrotron Light Research Institute in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand. Cu-K edge was investigated, and bulk CuO, Cu2O and Cu were used as Cu2+, Cu+, and Cu0 standards, respectively. Experimental data were collected in the transmission mode for Ce L3 and Cu K absorption edge with a Lytle detector. Synchrotron radiation is tunable by fixed-exit Double Crystal Monochromator (DCM) equipped with InSb(111) and Ge(220) crystal for low and high energy ranges, respectively. The samples were deposited over the Kapton window which was placed on the sample frame. Ion chambers were filled with a mixture of argon and helium. These chambers were installed in front of and behind the sample to continuously detect the incident (I0) and transmitted (I1) X-ray beams. 2.3 Reaction testing An amount of 150mg catalyst was loaded between two layers of quartz wool in a stainless-steel fixed bed flow reactor. The reactor was placed inside a tube furnace. The flow of feed gases was controlled by mass flow controllers (Aalborg). The initial feed gas of CO and N2 was mixed with water vapour which was controlled by using a syringe pump. Preliminary experiments were conducted to determine suitable conditions from which internal and external mass transfer effects are not predominant. Considering the effect of external mass transfer, the total flow rate was kept constant at 100mL/min in all testing. In addition, the catalyst particle size diameter was between 100 and 200μm in all experiments. The mixed feed gas composition of 5% CO, 10% H2O, balanced in N2 and of 100mL/min total flow rate was passed through the catalyst bed in the reactor. The temperature of catalysts was increased from 100°C up to 500°C. The column utilized in the chromatograph was a Unibead C, 15m×0.53mm stainless-steel packed column. The outlet gases were analyzed by using an on-line gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-14B) equipped with a TCD analyzer. The catalytic activities were calculated using equation [2]: (2) % C O c o n v e r s i o n = C O i n − C O o u t C O i n × 100 The rates of reaction were obtained from separate experiments where the conversions of reactants were lower than 30%. The rates were calculated using equation [3] (3) rCO = (FCO × XCO)/Wcat where rCO is the reaction rate of CO (molg−1 s−1), FCO is the molar flow rate of CO (mol/s) Wcat is the mass of the catalysts (g), and XCO is the conversion of CO. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of monometallic Cu catalysts XRD patterns of supports and Cu catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 . All samples exhibit diffraction peaks which correspond to the fluorite structure of CeO2. Very weak CuO diffraction peaks at 2θ of 35.7° and 39° can be observed in 5%Cu/CeO2(A), 5%Cu/CeO2(B), 5%Cu/GDC(C) and 5%Cu/GDC(D) catalysts. From N2O-chemisorption data and Cu elemental mapping in Figs. 3–4, 5%Cu/GDC(D) exhibits the highest Cu dispersion, while 5%Cu/CeO2(A) and 5%Cu/CeO2(B) shows lower Cu dispersion than that of other catalysts. 5%Cu/CeO2(B) has been prepared from nano-sized particle therefore the catalyst has rather high surface area. Moreover 5%Cu/CeO2(A) presented the lowest Cu dispersion which cannot be detected as shown in Table 1 . Based on Bragg’s equation, the lattice parameters of ceria and doped catalysts were calculated from (111) crystallographic plane. For pure CeO2 support, the lattice parameter is found to be 0.541nm which is in agreement with other works [20–22]. The lattice parameter of ceria in other catalysts (5%Cu/CeO2 and 5%Cu/GDC) also displayed similar values in the range of 0.0545–0.0547nm. From these results, it can be concluded that an addition of Cu did not lead to a significant modification of the ceria bulk structure or forming a solid solution between Cu and CeO2. Table 1 summarizes the results from particle analyses and XRD. Among the supported Cu catalysts, the BET surface area of 5%Cu/GDC(C) and 5%Cu/GDC(D) are higher than that of other catalysts. On the contrary, Cu/CeO2(A) shows the lowest BET surface area (1.2m2/g). For the comparison among the supports and catalysts, the BET surface areas of supported Cu catalysts are relatively lower than those of supports, indicating that the BET surface area decreases after Cu loading. Lowering of the surface area and increasing of ceria crystallite size of most of the catalysts are believed to be a consequence of calcination. The crystallite sizes of ceria supports in the catalysts were determined from X-ray line-broadening using the Debye Scherrer equation. 5%Cu/GDC(D) exhibits small ceria crystallite size, high surface area and the highest Cu dispersion. It is well known that a better dispersion of Cu yields a higher catalytic performance of supported Cu catalyst for WGS reaction. On the other hand, 5%Cu/CeO2(A) shows the largest ceria crystallite size, the lowest surface area and Cu dispersion. This result was due to particle agglomeration and the growth of ceria crystallites. Fig. 2 shows H2-TPR profiles of Cu on various supports. The reduction temperature of all samples is observed at temperature lower than 400°C. The 5%Cu/10%GDC (C) and 5%Cu/10%GDC (D) catalysts have three reduction peaks at about 150°C, 180°C and 200°C which are denoted as peaks β, γ, and δ, respectively. The peaks β, γ and δ assigned to finely dispersed CuO [23,24], the reduction of Cu2+ ions in the Cu-OCe solid solution [25,26], and bulk CuO particles [27–29], respectively. Interestingly, the peaks β, γ and δ of 5%Cu/10%GDC(D) are slightly shifted to lower temperatures compared to 5%Cu/10%GDC(C). It is expected that the easier reducibility of catalyst resulting in higher CO conversion. The H2-TPR profiles of 5%Cu/CeO2 (B) and 5%Cu/CeO2(combustion) exhibit two reduction peaks at about 140°C, and 200°C. The first peak appearing at about 140°C, denoted as peak α, is attributed to the reduction of non-crystalline copper oxide in close contact with ceria [30,31]. The second sharp peak is assigned to the reduction of Cu2+ ions in the CuOCe solid solution. For 5%Cu/GDC(combustion), only one reduction peak at high temperature corresponding to Cu2+ ions in the CuOCe solid solution was observed. Moreover, in the case of 5%Cu/CeO2(A), the peak β disappeared while H2 reduction peak corresponding to the reduction of Cu2+ ions in the Cu-OCe solution and reduction of bulk CuO particles shift to higher temperatures. SEM micrographs of the fresh Cu catalysts with the corresponding elemental mapping of three elements, including Ce, Gd and Cu. The elemental mapping of 5%Cu/GDC (D) and 5%Cu/GDC (C) revealed a quite homogeneous distribution of Cu, Gd and Ce species. However, it can be seen that the copper aggregates is observed in 5%Cu/CeO2(A) (Fig. 4 ). This is in good agreement with the TPR analysis. The reduction peak of 5%Cu/CeO2(A) correspond to a disappearance of finely dispersed CuO. 3.2 Water gas shift activity of monometallic Cu catalysts Fig. 5 shows activities of Cu on commercial CeO2 and GDC mixed oxide. It appears that 5%Cu/CeO2(A) and 5%Cu/CeO2(B) have weak WGS activity and start to convert CO to CO2 at temperature above 150°C. The activity of 5%Cu/CeO2(B) is slightly higher than that of 5%Cu/CeO2(A). Cu catalysts on GDC (C) and GDC (D) were more drastically active than Cu catalysts on ceria. The CO conversion of 5%Cu/GDC (D) starts above 100°C and rises up quickly to reach the maximum of 80% conversion at about 400°C. Above 400°C, the activity reaches equilibrium and slightly declines. The activities of 5%Cu/GDC (D) are drastically higher than the activity of 5%Cu/GDC (C). For 5%Cu/GDC (C) the conversion started above 100°C and rises up to reach the maximum of 75% conversion at 500°C. Catalytic activities of Cu on CeO2 and GDC prepared by a combustion synthesis technique are also studied. It can be seen that 5%Cu/CeO2(combustion) is not an active catalyst for WGS reaction. A modification of ceria with Gd drastically decreased the activity for WGS reaction. The order of activity at 500°C is; 5%Cu/GDC(D)>5%Cu/GDC(C)>5%Cu/CeO2(combustion)>5%Cu/CeO2(B)∼5%Cu/CeO2(A)∼ 5%Cu/GDC(combustion). For 5%Cu/CeO2(A), there is a drastic fall in the activity compared with other catalysts due to the reduction peak corresponding to a disappearance of finely dispersed CuO. An additional peak assigned to bulk CuO particles is observed at high temperature. Therefore, the TPR results directly evidenced that the finely dispersed CuO species is more efficient as active sites for WGS reaction. The formation of bulk CuO species is not beneficial for the activity. The finely dispersed CuO species supported on smaller CeO2 is favorable to the higher activity. Fig. 6 exhibits an Arrhenius plot of Cu on ceria and doped ceria, and the rate of WGS reaction at 400°C. The activation energy obtained from the slope of the Arrhenius plot as well as the reaction order in CO are summarized in Table 2 . It is noted that, from our study, the reaction orders in H2 and CO2 (Fig. 7 ) were close to 0 indicating the independence of CO2 and H2 on CO conversion rate, while CO reaction orders of all catalysts are in the range of 0.5–0.8. The Arrhenius plots show that the rates of CO conversion of 5%Cu/10%GDC (D), 5%Cu/10%GDC (C), and 5%Cu/CeO2 (Combustion) are much higher than the rates of other catalysts. A decline of the activation energy is also observed. 5%Cu/GDC(D) yields the highest WGS rate of 55.7μmol/gs. For the reaction on 5%Cu/CeO2(A), the rate is only 9.90μmol/gs. All the results from TPR and SEM analyses have led to conclude that the WGS rate depends on the surface area and distribution of Cu on a support. Moreover, an addition of Re on Cu/GDC (D) increases the rate of WGS reaction from 55.7μmol/gs to 61.6μmol/g.s. Lowering of apparent activation energy in Re-Cu/GDC (D) corresponds well with the increasing WGS reaction rate. 3.3 Water gas shift activity of bimetallic catalysts Since 5%Cu/GDC (D) was observed to be the best catalyst from the previous section, it was chosen for further study by adding 1%Re along with 4%Cu to be bimetallic of 1%Re4%Cu/GDC(D). H2-TPR profiles of monometallic and bimetallic catalysts are presented in Fig. 8 . For 1%Re/GDC(D) two reduction peaks are observed. The first at 387°C is attributed to reduction of rhenium oxide species. The other at 450 is due to reduction of surface ceria. The 5%Cu/GDC(D) catalysts have three reduction peaks at about 150°C, 180°C and 200°C which are assigned to finely dispersed CuO, the reduction of Cu2+ ions in the CuOCe solution solid, and bulk CuO particles, respectively. The H2-TPR of the bimetallic catalyst 1%Re4%Cu/GDC(D) is different from those of monometallic catalysts. In this case the surface reduction peak of ceria disappears and a concurrent reduction of metal oxide species appears at 174°C. An electron density transfer between Re, Cu, Ce and Gd may occur. As a result of electron density transfer, reduction of the catalyst surface is easier. Fig. 9 shows the WGS activity of monometallic 5%Cu/GDC (D) and bimetallic 1%Re4%Cu/GDC (D). It was found that the bimetallic catalyst 1%Re4%Cu/GDC (D) exhibited higher CO conversion rate compared to the monometallic catalysts, which became active at temperatures higher than 200°C and reached the maximum of 93% conversion at about 400°C. Above 400°C, the activity reached equilibrium and slightly decreased. The high WGS activity of bimetallic 1%Re4%Cu/GDC could be due to electron density transfer between Re, Cu, Ce and Gd, which may occur and result in a reduction of the catalyst surface becoming easier. 5%Cu/GDC (D) and 1%Re4%Cu/GDC (D) were further tested in a gas mixture containing 5%CO, 10%H2O and balance N2 at 350°C for 24h. The CO conversion vs. time plot is shown in Fig. 10 . The conversion of 5%Cu/GDC (D) dropped 7% in the first 4h and was then stabilized with a slight further decay. On the other hand, 1%Re4%Cu/GDC (D) retains a high WGS activity and stability for the whole period of 24h, since an addition of Re leads to more resistant toward deactivation. It is interesting to study the electron movement within the catalyst surfaces because the role of Re is crucial in enhancing the WGS activity of Cu on GDC(D). Hence, an X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) was employed to explain the electronic nature of these catalysts. The plots of XANES spectra and the edge energy shift of 1%Re/GDC (D), 5%Cu/GDC (D) and 1%Re4%Cu/GDC (D), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and CeO2 relative to the edge energy of Ce0 are displayed in Fig. 11 (a) and (b). It is clearly seen that XANES spectra of standard Ce(NO3)3·6H2O exhibits a single white line at 5725.5eV. The jump in energy in XANES spectra indicates energy required to raise electrons up from their core level to the unoccupied valence band in which it is called the edge energy. A linear fit was constructed through L3 energy shifts of Ce0, Ce3+ and Ce4+. The edge energy shifts of 1%Re/GDC (D), 5%Cu/GDC (D), and 1%Re4%Cu/GDC (D) relative to Ce0 was placed on this straight line at appropriate ΔE. The apparent oxidation states of Ce of these compounds lay between +3 and +4. The result indicates the coexistence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ in which Cu reduces the surface Ce4+ in CeO2 by transferring electron density into d-orbitals of Ce4+, leading to an existence of Ce3+. An evidence that electrons were transferred from Cu+ will be shown by increasing Cu oxidation states in the next section. Among these three catalysts, the oxidation state of Ce in 1%Re4%Cu/GDC (D) was the lowest. This result seems to indicate that Re assists Cu in reducing Ce4+ and giving rise to more Ce3+ at the surface of ceria support. The plot of XANES spectra and the edge energy shift of Cu+ and Cu2+ relative to the edge energy of Cu0 are displayed in Fig. 12 (a) and (b). A linear fit was constructed through the edge energy shift of Cu0, Cu+ and Cu2+. The edge energy shifts of 5%Cu/GDC (D) and 1%Re4%Cu/GDC (D) when plotted on this straight line indicate that the oxidation state of Cu in these compounds lies above +1. It can be concluded that the electron density was transferred from Cu+ to Ce4+ leading to an increase in oxidation state of Cu+ and lowering of oxidation state of Ce4+. For 1%Re4%Cu/GDC (D), the oxidation state of Cu+ is found to further increase. This result indicates that Cu+ also donates some electrons to Re leading to a further increase in its oxidation state. From these results, a conclusion can be drawn that Cu+ donates its electron to both Ce4+ and Re7+. 4 Conclusions The catalytic activity of Cu and Re monometallic and bimetallic catalysts on ceria based supports have been studied. Among Cu catalyst on various supports, 5%Cu/10%GDC(D) yields the highest catalytic activity which reaches the maximum of 80% conversion at about 400°C. The high catalytic activity of supported Cu catalysts is related to their smaller crystallite size of ceria support and higher Cu-dispersion. In addition, the TPR results directly evidenced that the finely dispersed CuO species is more favorable to have higher activity. The formation of bulk CuO species is not beneficial for the activity. Moreover, an addition of Re to Cu/10%GDC(D) drastically increased the catalytic activity to the maximum of 93% conversion at about 400°C. This result is due to an electron density transfer between Re, Cu, Ce and Gd which may occur, hence a reduction of the catalyst surface becomes easier. The effect of Re on enhancing the WGS activity of Cu catalysts was described using XANES. The XANES spectra indicates that Re assists Cu in reducing Ce4+ and giving rise to more Ce2O3 at the surface of the ceria support. The presence of Ce2O3 at the surface of ceria gives rise to oxygen vacancies which facilitate the electron movement at the surface leading to easier surface reduction. All of these effects contribute to an increase in the WGS rate. coredata.dc:description: In the present work, the water gas shift activities of Cu on ceria and Gd doped ceria were studied for a further enhancement of hydrogen purity after a steam reforming process. The catalytic properties of commercial catalysts were also studied to compare with our as-prepared catalysts. It was found that copper-containing cerium oxide is suitable for the high temperature reaction. Copper-ceria is a stable high-temperature shift catalyst, unlike iron-chrome catalysts which are deactivated severely in CO2-rich gases. 5%Cu/10%GDC (D) was found to have much higher activity than other copper ceria based catalysts. Finely dispersed CuO species is more favorable due to a higher activity, which explains the activity enhancement of this catalyst. The kinetics of the WGS reaction over Cu catalysts supported by mixed oxide materials were measured in the temperature range 200–400°C. An independence of the CO conversion rate on CO2 and H2 was observed. To improve the catalytic performance of copper catalysts, the behavior of the bimetallic catalysts was compared with that of the monometallic catalysts. It was found that an addition of Re to Cu/GDC significantly improved the activity of copper catalysts. The effect of Re on enhancing the WGS activity of Cu catalysts was due to Re increases the reducibility of the surface ceria, In addition, Re contributes to reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+. The presence of Ce2O3 at the ceria surface gives rise to oxygen vacancies which facilitate the electron movement at the surface leading to ease of surface reduction.
coredata.dc:title: Water gas shift reaction over monometallic and bimetallic catalysts supported by mixed oxide materials
